bibl.title: Letter from F.M. Boldridge to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1922

div1.p: Boldridge asks Carter for information on health conditions in Guatemala.

div1.head: Letter from F.M. Boldridge to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1922
div1.opener:
Mal
Boldridge
GEO. W. BYARS
MAYOR
J. H. McLURE
CITY ENG. AND TREAS.
F. M. BOLDRIDGE
HEALTH OFFICER
MARION & MARION
CITY ATTORNEYS
BOARD OF ALDERMEN
W. A. COLN
J. H. HAMILTON
O. A. LEE
J. A. NICHOLS
J. T. PEAY
O. M. PEDEN
W. C. WHITE
F. L. WHITLOCK
CITY OF CHESTER
SOUTH CAROLINA
CHESTER, S. C.
May 3rd 1922.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General, U.S.P.H.S.,
Washington, D.C. Res- # 2121 California St. N.W.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I have several friends who are contemplating
going to GUATEMALLA in the near future and they would like
very much to know all about the health conditions of that
country. The area in which they are contemplating going to,
is the SARSTOON RIVER VALLEY.

I would appreciate very much if you will
advise me as to the health conditions of this country, and
also your personal opinion as to whether or not you think
that several good American business men could make a success
there by purchasing and developing one hundred thousand or
more acres of land, that at present is well wooded and with
lumber that is easily worth a thousand dollars an acre, and
that which can now be purchased for less than a dollar per acre.

I understand from Mr. Sutton that they have
several more (new) cases to come up, and if they do I
certainly hope to have the pleasure of going over them with
you.

I certainly hope that your health has improved
and that you will be able to get down this summer or fall when
these cases are called.

Mr. Gaston is in Columbia to-day before the
Supreme Court discussing the Belton case.
Thanking you in advance for the above information,
